Title.evidence: Automated Temperature Management in Cardiopulmonary Bypass: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated a novel automated temperature management system

Participants.evidence: Participants were patients undergoing CPB, with eligibility criteria including age 18-75 and elective cardiac surgery. The study was conducted at a tertiary care hospital.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received automated temperature management, while the control group received standard manual management.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of cerebral hyperthermia, measured intraoperatively.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention and 100 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The automated system significantly reduced the incidence of cerebral hyperthermia (mean difference = 5.2%, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institute of Health.
